Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2013 02:22PM PaulAndSandy wrote: Ali68, JennH8's post was completely fine and answered the OP's question which was asking what things helped you make your decision regarding lumpectomy vs. mastectomy. While no one should purposely scare others into one treatment or another, this is also not a pep rally thread where only encouragement is given as the OP is asking for advice, not support. It is a personal decision and I think the OP genuinely wants to hear how others reached their own decision for inspiration or another point of view. My mother chose MX and was glad she did as it gave her 12 years of life with Stage IIIa IDC. In her case, with her staging and lymph node involvement, it was really the only choice the doctors recommended but still left it up to her to make.
Posts.Title: How did you decide on lumpectomy or mastectomy/ livingwithit IrishDancingMom

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2013 06:26AM PaulAndSandy wrote: Definitely go to the appointment. Better to be safe than sorry when it comes to this stuff. If it turns out to be nothing, at least you'll be able to get some relief from worrying about it.
Posts.Title: Freaking out Moondaiseez Moondaiseez

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 07:52AM PaulAndSandy wrote: I'm here on behalf of my mom... we both read the boards, have been for years, although she has always been extremely shy and never wants to post anything. She's been battling BC since Nov. 2001, nearly 12 years ago. She started as Stage IIIA in 2001, had a Stage II recurrence in 2010, and most recently in June of 2012, she found out she had become Stage IV with mets to the bones, spine, and liver. It's been a rollercoaster ride over the past 12 years and I have learned a LOT in that time from everyone, even going back to medical school for oncology at the suggestion of my mother's oncologists (I was told I knew more off the top of my head about very specific details of different chemos, treatments, mets, etc, than they knew and the way I discussed treatment options really helped them help my mom!) I promised my mom and her doctors I would do it and have been in medical school ever since. I'm glad we have a place like this for everyone to find info, share info, and give each other support. This disease makes me so angry sometimes because of what I see it doing to my mom and to all of you wonderful ladies. I'll be chiming in more now that I've temporarily moved in with my mom while she battles out this cancer. Unfortunately, she has deteriorated since November when she presented with large malignant pleural effusions around both lungs. The chemos have stopped working (we have our fingers crossed on the new Abraxane she's on) and she's beginning to lose hope... says she just needs to see a glimmer of hope somewhere and she hasn't seen it yet. I look forward to talking with you ladies more and wish all of you the very best! - Paul & Sandy (mom)
Posts.Title: Roll Call 2013 LilSchatzie reader123

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 08:22PM PaulAndSandy wrote: Danlias, Don't overthink the normal mammograms too much. My mother was diagnosed with Stage IIIA breast cancer in 2001 after noticing a very slight prickling sensation in her left breast. There was no lump, all of her mammograms came back normal every year, and even when they did the mammogram when she was diagnosed, it came back negative and the only reason they investigated further was because of the prickling sensation. By the time they finally saw it through more detailed scans, it was Stage IIIA with multiple node involvement. Sometimes no matter how proactive you are with self examinations and mammograms, these things can sneak up on you. With the constantly evolving treatments and drugs, there is more and more hope for people battling this disease. My mom went 8 years after her Stage 3A diagnosis before the cancer came back to the other breast and many other women have had even better outcomes with no recurrence or evidence of disease. I wish your mom the best... stay strong!
Posts.Title: Confused and scared danlias danlias

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2013 07:01AM - edited Feb 26, 2013 08:38AM by PaulAndSandy Danlias, The reason there are stages is to determine the type of caancer, how advanced it is, how far it has spread either locally, in surrounding tissues, or to distant organs or bone. Someone with a Stage I breast cancer has a very different cancer than someone with a Stage II cancer for example. Stage I means the cancer is smaller, less invasive, hasn't spread to lymph nodes (which increases the risk of it spreading to the other breast, surrounding tissue, or distant organs/bone) and is less likely to recur at a later time. Stage III breast cancers are more advanced, they've usually spread to the lymph nodes and need to be irradicated quicker and more agressively to reduce the chance of them coming back. Stage IV breast cancers have "metastasized" meaning they have spread to other parts of the body. This type of cancer is not curable but is treatable. Anyway, I hope this helps clear up some of the terminology in regards to the different stages and what they mean. This is obviously a very basic description--going into more detail really brings out just how confusing all of the stages are and what they mean. - Paul
Posts.Title: Confused and scared danlias danlias

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2013 08:18AM PaulAndSandy wrote: Hello Barb, my mother had a very similar situation in regards to the lung mets and the chemos you've been on. Mom was on Xeloda first but had progression and was switched to Doxil. She had progression and developed a malignant pleural effusion on Doxil so she was switched to Abraxane. Unfortunately, the Abraxane made her counts so low that the doctors couldn't bring them back up and she died due to organ failure. Because of the lung mets, the doctor was planning on trying Navelbine next. I researched it extensively and it sounded like a very good match for dealing with the lung mets. Sounds like your doctor is staying on top of things and I hope this new drug is the one that does the trick for you! - Paul

Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 10:01PM PaulAndSandy wrote: As others have said, a Stage IV diagnosis is almost a guanteed approval of SSDI. In my mom's case, not only was she approved once she found out she was Stage IV, but because her cancer was recurrent and she developed lymphodema years earlier from another BC surgery, they gave her 12 months of SSDI back pay. She was approved in August 2012, but they determined she was disabled from the lymphodema as of June 2009. They can only do back pay going back 12 months but at nearly $2k per month, she got a nice lump sum of $24k, plus $2k per month until she passed away last month. It definitely helped her financially and she didn't have to stress about not having money to enjoy the last year of her life. I talked her into applying because she kept saying, "They're not going to approve me so I'm not going to waste our time filling out the forms." Thank God we did! So yes, if you're getting that exhausted from work and you've worked all these years paying into SSI, that's what the SSDI is there for.
Posts.Title: Disability Retirement? Faith316 PaulAndSandy

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2013 01:33AM PaulAndSandy wrote: Mom was diagnosed in 2001 with Stage IIIa, several positive nodes. "To protect us" as she said, she always told us it was only stage I. She got 8 years before it came back to the other breast and another 2 years after that surgery before it spread to her organs and bone. She died a few months ago on May 2nd, almost 12 years after her Stage IIIa diagnosis. The best thing she did was to live life without constantly worrying about the cancer coming back. In the end, she got 12 years of quality life vs. 12 years of worry. - Paul

Posts.Title: Positive nodes with long term survival many Lily55

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2013 03:48PM PaulAndSandy wrote: CCRMom, My mother was also switched to Abraxane after she developed a malignant pleural effusion after it was determined the Doxil wasn't working. She didn't had too many SE's other than her blood counts dropped substantially to the point that she had to go from 3 weeks on, 1 week off, to 1 week on, 1 week off. Unfortunately, after 2 1/2 months on Abraxane, her counts dropped very low (WBC's were only 0.3 with the minimum being 3.0.) Her counts were fine before they gave her the chemo the last time but after a few days they must have dropped because she developed a mouth sore which turned into several mouth sores to the point she couldn't talk, all over the course of a couple days. They admitted her to the ER and gave her daily injections of Nupogen to try to boost the WBC's but unfortunately, even that didn't work. She passed away after 3 days in the hospital from sepsis caused by the low WBC's and subsequent mouth sores. I don't mean this to scare you but rather to make sure you know what to look out for in terms of SE's while taking this medication. Many women do completely fine with it, however, I have done a ton of research on this drug and have found many stories similar to my mom's so as with all chemo's be sure to watch out for any seriouis SE's and report them to your MO right away. In terms of the thoracentisis, I believe my mom had it performed 6 times total, each time draining close to a liter, sometimes more than a liter. I pushed the MO for a procedure called a PleurX which is where they insert a catheter into the pleural space and leave it there--you drain the fluid at home as the container fills up and it helps keep the fluid out of there. It also works (most of the time) to help close the pleural space by irritating the lining. This closing of the pleural space prevents further fluid from ever accumulating. They used to do a more invasive procedure called a pleurodesis wehich involved injected talc into the pleural space to cause the irritation and seal the space, however, that procedure is painful and was in-patient requiring sedation. The PleurX is as painless as a thoracentesis. Mom's MO was very conservative in his approach and wouldn't do the procedure (he thought the procedure could create a situation where an infection could occur) but be sure to mention it to your doctor and see what he/she says. It is only done if the pleural effusions become recurrent (more than 3.) Please let me know if you have any other questions about Abraxane, the SE's, or the pleural effusions and best of luck to you with the new treatment plan--hoping this one does the trick and beats it back! - Paul
Posts.Title: Just started Abraxane for newly diagnosed metastasis - any tips? CCRMom surfdreams

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 10:34PM PaulAndSandy wrote: This is a question I have really considered asking my mom's onc but I don't think he'd tell me and I know my mother doesn't want to know. Actually, it's not so much that she doesn't want to know, she's purposely blocking it out and talking about where she'll be in 5 years. Unfortunately, I don't have a good feeling about it as the cancer isn't just in her bones and liver anymore, it spread to the fluid around her lungs back in October last year causing a bi-lateral malignant pleural effusion. From what I've read, 4-6 months is what to expect when it gets to that point and the fact that she hasn't responded to the Xeloda or Doxil since her Stage IV diagnosis last June makes me even more worried. She's on Abraxane right now but after the first infusion her WBC went from 4.1 to 1.3 and they didn't give her the next infusion this week. (She's supposed to be 3 weeks on, 1 week off.) So, now she's getting a Procrit shot for her red blood cells, Nupogen for her WBC and ANC and I guess we'll see what happens from here. I'm not going to mention any of these prognosis to her because I don't want to depress her anymore than she already is. I do know many women live for years and years with mets, I'm just hoping my mom gets at least a couple. She's at 9 months right now.
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 09:53AM PaulAndSandy wrote: I agree with everyone but the only thing different I would add is, it's a good idea to at least have some sort of realistic timeframes if and when your cancer progresses to a certain point. For example, my mother is talking about moving to Texas next year and then only having to see an onc "every couple years for a tune-up." I don't think that's being very realistic when her cancer has spread to her bones, her liver, and most recently to the fluid around her lungs (bi-lateral malignant pleural effusion.) She is weak, has lost 40 lbs over the past 4 months, has been hospitalized 4 times over the past two months for infection and dehydration, her chemos have not been effective, and the latest chemo while we're not sure if it will work, is really bringing her counts down to levels that make her unable to receive her next chemo infusion as scheduled. I really want to sit her down and tell her about being more realistic about life, not planning things out so far in advance, enjoying the time she has NOW, and making sure her affairs are in order. Unfortunately, my father and brothers are siding with her and feeding into this mindset. It's as if if everyone is in denial about what's going on. What I fear is that she'll get really bad and die in the hospital instead of at home where she wants to because she won't even discuss the word "hospice" let alone agree to receive hospice care. I hear from a lot of women on here who are very open and realistic about their diagnosis, have all of their affairs in order, hospice lined up just in case it's needed, etc. I really wish my mother was like this but unfortunately she's always been the exact opposite, ignoring the suggestions of hospice and concealing symptoms to avoid having to admit there's a problem and in turn be admitted or even worse, be told the cancer is getting worse. Very frustrating experience for the caretaker, that's for sure. I hope she comes around and at least lets us help her get her affairs in order and ensure that she dies with dignity in the manner she wants to, at home.
Posts.Title: Prognosis Kazzie61 curveball

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2013 09:20AM - edited Oct 7, 2013 09:25AM by PaulAndSandy Ativan, Xanax, and Valium are the three most effective to relieve anxiety. There are several others like Visteral and Buspar that are non-addictive and in my opinion, non-effective. To me, they were like taking skittles for anxiety. You have to find a good doctor who's willing to put your mental health above his/her insecurities with prescribing anything "addictive." Too many doctors these days refuse to prescribe effective anxiety medications or pain medications because of how hard the government has been cracking down on them for it. This is mostly due to drug abusers making it hard for the rest of us to get the medications we need. To answer your question, since I have taken all three and am currently taking two: Ativan (lorazepam) works the best for me and I can still function with it. It lasts the longest though (4-5 hours) which I don't Iike. I would rather have it relieve the anxiety and then leave my system. Xanax (alprazolam) works very quickly and hits you like a brick. Wouldn't feel 100% safe driving on it, especially when first taking it or when when you already feel tired. It only lasts about 2 hours which is nice. Valium is the stronger of the three but only works for about an hour. Not a good idea to drive on this one. I would suggest looking into the Xanax. You'd probably have to take it at least an hour or so before you're going to drive but it does a good job and doesn't stay in your body making you feel too out of it for long. Definitely talk to a doctor about about the different options and if you have a doctor who straight up refuses to prescribe these medications because "they're addictive," find a new doctor who will put your health before his/her insecurities.
Posts.Title: Anxiety meds Lauriesh Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2013 07:26AM PaulAndSandy wrote: My mom's BC produced no palpable lump, was 2cm in size and wasn't picked up on the first mammo. She described a pricky feeling, almost like a needle, on the side of her breast near her arm pit. It wasn't until the second mommo where they were specifically looking for it in that area that they found it. The second cancer which occurred in the other breast had no pain, discomfort or feel to it as it presented as micro-calcifications. I think this really proves why regular mammos from a reputable doctor or clinic is so important. You won't always feel or see a lump.

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2013 02:51AM PaulAndSandy wrote: My Mom was originally diagnosed Stage 3A back in November 2001 and after having a mastectomy, followed by Adriamycin and Taxotere along with radiation, she stayed free of cancer on Tamoxifen for 8 years when it came back in the other breast in November 2010 as Stage 2A. Another mastectomy, more chemo and she got almost another 2 years before it spread to her bones and liver in June 2012 and became Stage IV. She has remained positive over these past 12 years and she still tries to stay positive even as she struggles today. She made a decision 12 years ago to keep her Stage 3A diagnosis from all of us over the years, telling us it was only Stage 1 because she didn't want us to worry or alter our lives. Part of me is glad she did because I wasn't worrying every day--but another part of me wishes she would have said something so I was able to come to terms with her diagnosis. She is completely open about it now... I follow each treatment and consult with her oncologists to develop new treatment plans. I guess the point I'm trying to make is, don't let your Stage 3A diagnosis emotionally consume you day after day, year after year. No matter what the prognosis' are and no matter what anyone tries to tell you, each of you is a unique person and your story is YOUR story and no two people's battles are the same. I know my story is not of the cheering, survivor type that all of the others appear to be but I think it's still important to share. I wish all of you the very best and if anyone ever has a question, please feel free to ask.
Posts.Title: stage 3a breast cancer survivors mariar Icandoallthings

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2013 02:30AM PaulAndSandy wrote: It's definitely a very personal choice. My mother chose to only tell us kids and my father and after a few months, her brothers and sisters. And that was about the extent of it. She's always remained very private about it over the past 12 years through all 3 diagnosis' and tries to minimalize how serious her condition is, especially with her Stage IV diagnosis back in June of 2012. She would deny it was Stage IV, didn't want to update anyone in the family, didn't want anyone to know. She has slowly eased up because she's been forced to--my father had to take family medical leave from work to help with her care so his co-workers knew (he's a nurse so it was a bunch of medical staff), I had to temporarily move in with her up in Ohio to care for her over the past couple months so my partner had to stay at our home in Texas with the dogs. I'm lucky enough to have started several very successful businesses over the years and am able to delegate all of my previous responsibilities to my staff and manage the businesses online from Ohio. Point is, at some point in time, people will usually find out but I think 99% of the time, that's a good thing. Almost everyone who has founf out about my mother's diagnosis has been extremely supportive. Even the nurses and doctors at my father's work who he thought weren't very good friends of his have stepped up, sent cards every day, sent care packages, covered shifts for him, etc. The support mean so much to everyone. Whatever you choose, I wish you the very best with your journey and I hope you keep us posted and come back here to talk with everyone. This place is full of tons of wonderful women (and men!) that are in the same fight or helping someone who is. - Paul
Posts.Title: how many people will I tell about the cancer? kpr msphil

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2013 12:14AM PaulAndSandy wrote: When my mother was diagnosed, she never received any orientation, books, or other literature other than a piece of paper or two with appointment times and so forth. She was lucky in that her MO and his nurse were very well coordinated and worked out of a major cancer center in Cleveland, Ohio where literally every resource was at their disposal. Mom passed away last month on May 2nd at the hospital where she received her treatments and even up until her last day with us, her care was well coordinated. The only thing we had to do was to inform her MO and his staff of any complications, SE's, or other problems, and they would usually have us come in same day. So to answer the OP's question, if you don't feel you're getting the type of service you deserve, I would strongly consider talking to some other people in your area and see if you can't find a better match. Mom stuck with her MO for the full 12-years but my grandmother had to switch twice because of problems with coordination of care. Many of the men and women I've talked to about this have said the main reason they don't end up switching providers is that they're afraid something will get screwed up in the mix, paperwork will be lost, the new MO will take a totally different approach and the cancer will progress, etc. One of those, "if it's not broke, don't fix it" type things. Personally, I would switch in a heartbeat if I felt my care team was missing things or was treating me like a number.
Posts.Title: Coordination of Your Care: What's Your Experience EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: May 8, 2013 10:31AM PaulAndSandy wrote: Thank you everyone for your kind words and condolences! Dad has been overwhelmed with the amount of support he's seen in the support group he attended and here on BCO from all of you wonderful ladies. It means a lot to all of us. - Paul
Posts.Title: {{{ Sandy is an Angel }}} PaulAndSandy justjudie

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2013 01:24AM PaulAndSandy wrote: My mom passed away a couple months ago from breast cancer after it too had spread. She did very well after her first diagnosis in 2001 but once it spread to her other organs, she only survived 11 months, 3 months after it spread to her lungs. I too would suggest spending as much time with her and your father as you can. The sock thing made me smile because I used to get my mom these warm fuzzy socks that she liked and when she couldn't walk anymore, would take her for drives through the park which she loved! She used to hike every day and missed being out in the wilderness. Another suggestion I would make is having your mom and dad fill out a "story of my life" type book... they sell them on Amazon and there are many to pick from... They are great because they are a workbook style format that your mom would fill out. Everything from her favorite colors and foods, memories from childhood, stories about how she met your father, childhood friends and so on. Unfortunately, my mom died before I had a chance for her to fill it out because she got too weak too quickly but we've been able to fill much of it out after she died thanks to family and friends. This would be a keepsake to pass onto your children. Wishing you, your mom, and your dad the very best as you fight this cancer! We're all here for you so feel free to ask anything you'd like. - Paul
Posts.Title: Holding on by a thread walkaway walkaway

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2013 12:13PM PaulAndSandy wrote: I have mixed feelings about this. On one hand, if we ever want to find a cure or at least better treatments and drugs, we need to raise money. At the same time, I feel that a lot of the pink ribbon crap is just that: a commercialized joke. How many times do you go to the store now and half the boxes of foods have a pink ribbon on them, how many commercials on television somehow work in a pink ribbon, how many people who know next to nothing about what breast cancer is REALLY about have a faded pink ribbon magnet on the back of their car? To me it seems like it's become so commercialized. I don't donate to Komen, I don't donate to any of the big charities because there's too much overhead and not enough money going directly into research. Instead I donate to individual research projects. Over the years, I've been fortunate enough with the companies I have started that I've been able to donate tens of thousands of dollars to various research projects and will continue to do so even when my mother finally dies from this disease. I've even taken it a step further and started a project with my mom's help to SHOW what breast cancer really is. A pink ribbon doesn't show the monster that is breast cancer. It doesn't show the physical scars, the emotional scars, the fear, the hope, the worry, the peace, or any of the other feelings, emotions, and physical trauma associated with it. We're helping those battling breast cancer to SHOW what this disease is by having themselves photographed, scars and all, and writing a summary of what breast cancer has meant for them, how they deal with it, how they don't deal with it. These photographs and stories will be published in a book so that maybe it will give some support for those newly diagnosed or those who need something to help them relate with others in a similar situation. Well I'm ranting now so I'll stop. But that's my take on it.

Posts.Title: Liver mets sypmtoms Evans1128 soleil505

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2013 03:27PM PaulAndSandy wrote: I personally take Norco 10/325 for chronic back pain (herniated discs, cyst between T4-T5, pinched nerves between L4-L5, and the list goes on). Have been on them for 6 years now, 4 times per day and they have controlled the pain, especially when used with Ibuprofin. My mother who is the one with the BC with mets to the bones, spine, liver, and lungs, takes half of one when the pain gets bad along with 600mg of Ibuprofen and she's fine with that. In terms of the Morphine, I had it right after my back injury and got the same sleepy feeling at first but after my body adjusted to it, much of the drowsiness went away and the pain was controlled. From what I was told by my neurosurgeon, until your body adjusts to the new medication, you can get some extreme drowsiness from it. I'm hoping they find a solution that works for you. Bone pain is unbearable, often times worse that severe tooth pain and always seems the hardest to manage. - Paul
Posts.Title: Morphine Mzmerz Naniam

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2014 05:02PM PaulAndSandy wrote: It certainly doesn't hurt to get a second opinion but at the same time, no matter what, the tumors need to be removed and a good oncologist and surgeon at a good hospital should be able to do this.  What you'll want to think about is are you going to have a single mastectomy or a bilateral mastectomy. My mom chose a single mastectomy and then regretted it when the cancer came back to the other breast years later. She wished she would've done the bilateral mastectomy because it would have saved her life. The cancer that came back in the other breast was only Stage 2 but came back a year later as Stage 4. Unfortunately, she passed away last May from the cancer after battling it for nearly 12 years.  So I really think this is one of the biggest decisions you'll need to make and you may want to get a couple opinions, ask around on the forums, etc.  Wishing you the best with your treatment!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed this week. How many opinions should I have? Luppie edwards750

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2013 10:01AM PaulAndSandy wrote: Mom was so happy when her port was taken out in 2010 but was relieved when it was put back in in 2012 when she was dx with mets. So much easier for labs, IV fluids, chemo, transfusions, IV meds and so on. She hated nothing more than the lab techs and nurses digging for a vein every week. I think a lot has to do with how well the port is implanted and the skill of the surgeon or physician's assistant who's performing the surgery. I've heard from many women who say the port was implanted on their left side--this is the wrong location but its easier (lazy) for the surgeon to place it there. It involves putting in more tubing which can ultimately make the port more uncomfortable.

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2013 08:09AM PaulAndSandy wrote: I am glad this post was started because this has been something on my mind for a while now. While my mom had a husband (my dad) and 3 boys to help out, when she started to get really sick, I was trying to imagine how she'd be if she were alone. She went from fully independent to having me, her 31 year old son give her her daily showers, help her get dressed, clean her up when the chemo caused her to have an accident, and so forth. She was very opposed to it at first as would be expected, but started to become more comfortable as she needed me more. I thought it would create a weird awkwardness with my mom but in the end it helped create a special bond she would have never had with 3 sons and no daughters. Anyway, sorry for the rambling post, I just wanted to say how much this thread helped me understand how others are handling their treatments without a partner or children to help. All of your stories are very uplifting and you are all brave for being able to do this in a more independent fashion than others typically do.
Posts.Title: Anyone single and doing this cancer business ? diana50 gonegirl
